author: sebastiengllmt
title: Solve asset fractionalization
description: Multiple bridges connected to Milkomeda and Cardano result in the creation of multiple assets (derivatives) which fragment liquidity (of the same asset e.g. USDC) and impact UX in protocols.

f6_assessments.q0: The fragmentation of liquidity might be a bit complex to understand for the average Cardano user, but this problem impacts UX in protocols and makes such activities as trading harder. The proposed solution - canonical smart contract can solve this problem so I think Cardno Project Catalyst voters could prioritize this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: Milkomeda team is very experienced so there are no doubts that they can accomplish this proposal. To be honest I think that the plan and the budget breakdown could be with more details. But the competence of people like Sebastien Guillemot and Rob Kornacki is very high, so I’m putting 5 stars to this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The major reason why I decided to put 5 stars is that the team behind this proposal has already many other accomplished projects and many completed Project Catalyst proposals. The audit could be done easily on all stages from Proof of concept, MVP demo to Deployment to Milkomeda sidechain.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal effectively addresses the challenge. The team has created Milkomeda which enables the existing cross-chain infrastructure on Cardano. Creating easier user experiences around cross-chain usage makes a lot of sense given the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind the proposal has an extensive history of success. that has delivered many projects to the Cardano blockchain. The confidence in their capacity to hit deliverables is rather high. 

The deployment of this project over a 3 month period with an audit does a good job of ensuring that the end product will be of quality and function as intended.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposed solution portion of the proposal does provide a sense of what the proposal aims to accomplish. The attached document goes into further detail on this and includes general user flows. One suggestion would be adding a bit of context to certain more complicated topics. This would help readers who may not understand how bridges work.

The main risks section give a general overview of where issues could arrive around deliverables. That being said a more in-depth description of difficulties around complexity and how that is solved would be great to add. 

The detailed plan provides the milestones need to be successful with the project. It would be great to get a sense of how much each milestone will take to deliver on.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to solve the issue of creating multiple wrapped/derivatives that are creating to work on multiple chains e.g. ada/eth, and therefore it might be more complicated and confusing for users, when too many assets emerge. The solution proposed by proposers is to create so called “canonical smart contract” that which will be used for exchange of whitelisted assets by their “canonical” version that can be used in Cardano ecosystem. Unfortunately, the term “canonical” is lacking clarity, as it was not elaborated nowhere in the text, whether it is just name created by proposers, or it actually reflects attribute of these assets. For better clarity, an example could have been used, because right now it is not very clear. The simples explanation I came up with is that user can trade wrapped tokens e.g. wrapped ADA for ADA in cardano ecosystem, because having wrapped ADA in Cardano ecosystem is not making sense. The proposers also state, that the amount of tokens that can be swapped using these canonical smart contracts will be limited. I think in the long run, this protocol can keep the Cardano ecosystem more clean, from the perspective of different assets, and their wrapped versions. I am taking one star down because of the lack of clarity of the proposed solution.
f6_assessments.q1: The roadmap is actually not stated, and we have the list of milestones for overview such as PoC, implementation bridge to Milkomeda,  Audits, Open source codebase and deployment. For better clarity, the time frame should be set – how many months/weeks it will take? Then at least the first phase e.g. first month could have been estimated in weeks, for better picture. The total budget requested is 90 000 USD, and 45k is for three months of deployment and development (but we do not know whether it is full time, or no, and we also do not know how many people will work on that, as well what is the proposed hourly wage). 4 500 USD is for catalyst management, but it is unclear what it represents, as well as project management could have contain more information (time frame, people, hourly wage). The team is having 4 members, and proposer state that one of the core developer will work on the development with Sebastian and Rob – which is not actually providing more clarity, rather it is more confusing – three people will be developing? Who is the “core Milkomeda dev”?, what is the expected time donation? Linked in profile, or some bio? Even tough you are having working product already (Milkomeda), for newcomers or people not using it, it should have been disclosed and elaborated. Not every voter is keeping his information up to date. Right now, based on the information in the proposal, there is too many information missing. Stars taken down for lack of clarity for roadmap, budget and team.
f6_assessments.q2: The problem solution is somehow clear, and regarding progress KPIs, there are only milestones from roadmap stated, thus, without clear time distinction, we are unable to track the progress. I suggest to proposers to provide some reports (monthly, weekly) on some public channel (telegram, twitter, discord). Regarding success KPIs/metrics, the proposer state that “correct deployment” will be measured, and al least one usage of this protocol within one month after development. Well, if the solution is to improve user experience and also to increase cross-chain collaboration, thus I believe success metrics should be focused on the amount of tokens e.g. whitelisted, transferred (number/volume of transactions), and its increasing trend in the time.

f6_assessments.q0:
Yes, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge by improving the user experience and mitigating the fractionalization of assets when moving between chains. This proposal aligns perfectly with the challenge for cross chain collaboration. 

Milkomeda is a bridge from other chains to Cardano, whereby different assets (say from Ethereum) can be ported over and used on Cardano. When this project first went live it was a major milestone in the community, and the team continues to deliver. However, as noted in the proposal there are still some issues with the bridge, such that assets can be fractionalized through the porting process, which limits liquidity and makes for a poor user experience. 

This new smart contract will allow users to use a canonical version of assets and in so doing reduce the fractionalization issue. Getting this right could make such bridges more appealing to other blockchain users not on Cardano, while also benefiting the entire ecosystem by welcoming new people.
f6_assessments.q1:
Yes, given experience and plan presented it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully. 

The Milkomeda team has an excellent track record in Cardano and has become a strong faction that is delivering utility to Cardano each fund. The team clearly knows what is needed and there is no doubt they can succeed in achieving it. 

Why I am only giving 4/5 is that the plan and budget leave a bit to be desired. While I have faith in the team, there should be a better description of the solution for voters. For example, the team is asking for $90k but it's sparse on details. What are the activities that go into each of the steps? How what is the estimated timeframe for completion? 

Providing a more detailed roadmap, budget breakdown, and expected time to delivery would increase this section to full marks.
f6_assessments.q2:
Yes, the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and success of the proposal. 

Again, the strength of the auditability section is that the Milkomeda team has been very upfront and engaging with auditing all parts of their project. They provide good close out reports and their success is witnessed through the use of their application (bridge). 

One thing that could have been improved here to increase the score is a better breakdown of the steps under each of the stages. It would be nice to have a sense of what steps go into creating the MVP and how the community might be able to track or follow along with their progress. 

I commend the team on their work but would note that I think it's important for the proposers to remember that not all voters have the same level of expertise. Sometimes providing small pieces of info that may feel superfluous would actually go a long way to getting your message and idea across.

f6_assessments.q0:
dcSpark, the company that created Milkomeda has a new proposal for creating a smart contract as an attempt to solve the issue of asset fractionalization when tokens are sent to / from Cardano via different bridges.
The proposer has added a detailed plan on how to approach this issue, based on the requirements for this functionality. Risks were also identified, namely that for this kind of smart contract, very much attention must be paid to security. To guarantee the highest degree of security possible, the most experienced people in the company will be working on this project and upon completion, a third party auditor will be contracted to verify the code.
I fully agree that this proposal effectively addresses the Cross-Chain Collaboration challenge. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has provided a plan with the milestones which need to be delivered here, starting with a proof of concept and ending with the deployment of the contract to Milkomeda. The only missing thing here is the timeline. We are not given an estimation of approximately how long this project will take to complete in the plan itself. An estimation is however present in the budget breakdown and it’s 3 months. Regarding the sum itself, 90000 USD is a considerable ask, but for a team of at least 4 experienced people in the domain, for 3 months, it’s actually not that much (it’s stated that only about 70% of the sum goes to development, while 30% or more will go to the audit).
Regarding the team, we are given a few names of dcSpark employees (please consider also adding linkedin / other relevant profile links to them in the future for easier verification). Since these are the people who built Milkomeda in the first place, as well as many other solutions in the Cardano ecosystem, I think it is highly likely for this proposal to be implemented successfully. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q2:
As measures of progress, the proposer used the detailed plan again, implying that as every step is completed, this will be communicated publicly, so that the community can know (please be sure to be explicit next time on how this information will be shared). Also please consider adding KPI’s with clear numeric targets, as per the proposer guidelines, to help with auditability.
The measure of success is very clear, in that the expectation is to have at least one protocol in Milkomeda and one in Cardano use this solution for a major asset like USDC within 1 month of its deployment.
I think the information here is sufficient to audit the progress and success of the proposal. Score: 5.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea of ​​the proposal that create a new work flow to deal with asset fragmentation in Defi's cross-chain bridge protocols implemented via the Mikomeda sidechain.  A canonical bridge is created to collect all the assets locked at other cross-chain bridges. This proposal basically meets the criteria set by the challenge:
1. New technical implementations connecting Cardano to other blockchains and vice versa (SDKs, APIs, bridges etc)
2. Already successful projects expanding from other chains to Cardano
3. Expansion of Cardano-based projects into other chains
Overall, this is a very good solution for effective asset management in Defi. Despite some of the challenges that the proposal raises, I confuse about the effectiveness of this solution.
1. Many bridges will move into a common bridge, which means one more intermediate bridge will be added. Increase 1 level of complexity for the level of assurance, avoiding asset loss.
2. The management of accounts will be more complicated. Just as the proposer has given an example where the user is trying to "open" amount X but the standard demand has only a fraction of the amount X, it will fail.
From the perspective of a regular Defi user, I would evaluate this solution as a potential risk to my assets.
From there, we can see that the problem of this solution still revolves around the two main issues of cross-chain bridge protocols: security and the level of security for assets locked into the protocol. However, looking at the positive side, I still think this proposal is very interesting in terms of ideas when it comes to trading safety with efficiency in capital use. Maybe this proposal will have a good impact on the easygoing Defi user community and those who have confidence in the proposal implementation team.
f6_assessments.q1:
The details plan of the proposal is quite sketchy, with only major milestones and lack of specific timelines. There are 6 work items listed and the implementation and completion time is 3 months (refer to budget breakdown). But the timelines for each specific task are not clearly stated by the proposer. At this point, the proposer should give timelines in monthly units so that he can better assess the feasibility of the proposal.
Budget breakdown is divided into 4 parts as follows:
a) 50% development and deployment (3 months): $45000
b) 30-40% audit: 27000-36000$
c) 15% project management: 13500$
d) 5% catalyst management: $4500
I do not accept 3 costs b, c, d and assume cost b is 30%. Cost a) then in my opinion, the proposer should list in detail what the related work will include so that the voter can see more clearly. For example:
development and deployment: 45000
- Proof of concept / demo MVP: 5000
- Implementation of canonical bridge connected to validators of Milkomeda: 20000
- Open sourcing of codebase: 5000
- Deployment to Milkomeda C1: 10000
The team that implements the proposal is a very popular team in the Cardano community. With Cardano's wide range of products and technical contributions. The capacity of the Dcspark team is that there is no need for further verification. They are fully capable of implementing this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
There are 6 milestones as in the detail plan of the proposal that can serve as the basis for tracking project progress:
a) Proof of concept / MVP demo
b) Implementation of canonical bridge connected to validators of Milkomeda
c) Audit by 3rd party
d) Audit fixes
e) Open sourcing of codebase
f) Deployment to Milkomeda C1
This watchlist is in line with the roadmap for the 1 product the proposal wants to create. However, so that the community can follow it transparently and clearly. It is recommended to provide a way to track such as checking at which source? maybe the community is quite familiar with Dcspark's github but within the scope of a proposal, the community still needs the relevant information outlined in the proposal. In addition, it is recommended to add specific timelines to create initiative for those performing audit activities.
According to the proposal, the project will be successful when the correct deployment of the canonical bridge and the usage of at least one protocol in Milkomeda and one in Cardano for at least one of the major assets (like USDC) in the first month after deployment. But in my opinion the proposal will have great success if the Defi user community accepts the solutions as well as the trade-offs that the project brings. However, this will need to be observed in the near future before conclusions can be drawn.

f6_assessments.q0: I have tried using Milkomeda several times to get myself some good ERC-20 tokens using my ADA. I can say the issue mentioned in this proposal is real. Moreover, no better challenge to address this issue other than Cross-Chain Collaboration! When doing a swap, I noticed that my transaction caused bigger price movement or higher slippage sometimes but sometimes not. And upon using different bridge, I found the price difference of the asset among bridges is quite significant, sometimes can be more than 1%. Yes, it is an arbitrage opportunity but is not ideal for normal users who wants a CEX-like user experience (UX) or newcomers/guest from other chains accustomed to the better UX in their home chain. To me, conclusively this proposal is a solid 5 due to its alignment with the challenge where it is submitted and the overall benefit of better performance of and experience in Cardano thus leading wider adoption and higher level of utilization. No better time to achieve this now other than during Basho era of interoperability and scalability that we are in now!
f6_assessments.q1:
dcSpark has time and time again proven themselves as one of the premier builders in Cardano ecosystem. I noticed that they are becoming more expert in inter-blockchain bridges solutions and currently this is their niche now. For voters who are new in Cardano, dcSpark consists of OG Cardano builders like Seba, Nic, and Rob who used to work for Emurgo, one of the founding entities of Cardano alongside Input Output Global (IOG) and Cardano Foundation. To check their track record, you can go to their website www.dcSpark.io and from there you can check and verify their track records and what they have been doing either in Github, Twitter, or LinkedIn. Product portfolio of the dcSpark includes Milkomeda itself as the first bridge solution from Cardano and Flint wallet, multi-chain focused, Web3 wallet. In addition to products and dApps, the founders are also active contributors in general Cardano community, be it through education contents and the development of tools and infrastructures necessary for the advancement Cardano ecosystem such as Cardano Improvement Proposals (CIP).

Regarding the budget, I have calculated the hourly rates of each function by breaking down the badge and assuming 13-14 working weeks with conservative 40-hour working hours each week. The results are USD 43 for two developers, USD 26 for a project manager, USD 26 for each of two security auditors, and USD 8.5 for the general and administrative Catalyst management. I must say the rate is fair and comparable to other proposals submitted in Catalyst during this Fund 9. The proposer also stated that the team most likely do not need further or additional funding to deliver this solution for now. However, an improvement such as adding DAO feature to govern and curate the asset whitelist per bridge can be proposed and implemented in the future Catalyst funds. Plans with key milestones are also presented though it can be refined further relative to other similar proposals in Catalyst. For further understanding on technical aspects such as solution architecture and design implementation, the proposer has given a link to a Google doc detailing information above.

Lastly, I think the proposer should inform and educate that inter-blockchain bridge is inherently a quite risky infrastructure since many hacks happened at this point of failure so far. One of the most recent and significant accident happened is Horizon bridge exploit in Harmony One blockchain costing USD 100 million. Although for now, the proposer had addressed and explained that the security risk in the proposal implementation itself is minimal and they are trying to prevent and mitigate it with high-assurance and quality coding practice and contracting more than one high-quality security auditors to double check the works.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer mentioned that the development and deployment of the proposed solution to asset fractionalization will be delivered in 3 months which is fair and honestly quite fast for me and I will take that as a win for the Cardano community. Success is defined by the correct deployment of the canonical bridge as consolidation solution from the fragmentation of various bridges in Milkomeda. Proposer also mentioned that at least one protocol in Milkomeda and one in Cardano using the bridge for at least one major asset e.g. USDC in the first month after deployment. I think this metric is fair since USDC itself is already an asset of significant market value as the only fiat stablecoin that can be used in Cardano without using centralized exchange (CEX).

I believe dcSpark can also mention utilizing their social media such as Twitter, Medium, and Discord for regular updates to interested audience. Mentioning AMA sessions could also be a great way to communicate with general and wider member of communities either in Cardano or other blockchains. Their Github is also busy and could provide some more technical updates about what’s going on there.

solution: The creation of a canonical smart contract where whitelisted assets (and bridges) can exchange their bridged asset by a canonical version that will be used by the Cardano ecosystem.
experience: The team is part of the core developers of Milkomeda and it has developed multiple critical infrastructure tooling for Cardano e.g. cardano-serializaion-lib, carp, Flint, CIPs, etc.
